newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Microsoft opens two new offices in Africa.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft opens two new offices in Africa.

text.p: Microsoft Corp said on Wednesday it had opened two new offices in east and west Africa as part of its expansion drive on the continent.
The offices were opened in December and January in Abidjan, Ivory Coast and Nairobi, Kenya and Microsoft Regional Africa managing director Rob Katz said it had cost "hundreds of thousands of rands".
Katz said it was Microsoft policy not to reveal figures for individual subsidiaries.
"We have opened two new offices in Abidjan and Nairobi. This shows that Microsoft is not a short-term organisation but is committed to the region," Katz told a news conference.
Kenya and Ivory Coast were two of the most developed countries in terms of infrastructure, Katz said.
He said it was hoped that the offices would grow into full subsidiaries with time, offering the full level of product support services.
"Africa is the last developing region in the world. We hope to have 10 to 20 new sales offices in Africa by the year 2000," business manager for Regional Africa Phil Allcock said.

Revenue generated in Regional Africa -- Africa south of the Sahara desert excluding South Africa and including the Indian Ocean Islands -- grew to 20 percent of total Africa revenue in 1996 from one percent in 1993.
Total revenue from Regional Africa represented less than one percent of total Microsoft revenue, Katz said.
Microsoft opened its South Africa office in 1992 with a view to using it as a base to expand into Africa south of the Sahara.
Allcock said part of the problems experienced in entering Africa were high excise duties ranging from 15 to 40 percent leading to pirating of software and poor communication infrastructure.
Katz said they saw Africa in the same league in 10 years with east Asian countries.
"We are expecting Africa to be our next big market. The business opportunities there are untapped and require 'hands on' management to understand the market dynamics of each country," he said.
